column187:
10/Nov/21 10:22 AM;andy.chan@rtx.com;Donna Sanford Inputs:

I met with Matt Ramsey to understand what this extra $2M was for and to determine if it was anywhere in the business case. 

 

Here’s what I learned.  DXC bid a solution or a tool in their offering for a more modern solution for asset management, audit alerting and operations for the LAN/ Wireless Lan/VOIP.  DXC put in the licensing cost but the deal was that RTX would pay for the servers, storage, and backup to run the tool.  This is what the $2M annually is for.  

 

On the hUTC side there is no tool currently doing this job and they are not compliant currently.   hUTC needs this tool. 

 

On the hRTN side we currently use IPCENTER from IBM for our monitoring tool.  We pay about $322K annually under 91150 the NOC.  This can’t go away immediately there will be a transition period.  Eventually at some point they will be incorporated into the DXC’s tool so that all of the RTX L:AN/WLAN/VOIP can be on the same tool.

 

Matt and I brainstormed where we could charge this since we don’t have a LAN RTX home office that can allocated to all 4 business units.

 

The known increase during the 2022 AOP exercise is for the identified labor ($1.8M) necessary for this synergy and it was determined to put that “dis-synergy”  into cc 817 which is allocated across net sales. Using 817 for this increase - Rockwell Collins is not part of this deal and they would be charged for it.  Even if we picked 822 that will get allocated across headcount and Rockwell Collins would still get cost from that as well.  This monitoring will tie back to 10,000 devices and could be allocated based on that  but that would require a whole monitoring and charging system to operate which would require a lot of care and feeding.  To put that into Tango would flood it (almost double what it is today)  and there is a cost putting that amount of lines into that system. 

 

Our conclusion is to just put it into a cost center that allocates over net sales.  91150 or 817.  817 is on the hUTC side might be a little easier to get on that contract.  But that is for Rick Dombrowski’s team labor.  At least 91150 would be for the tool.  (There is an offset in that the labor that starts charging in Jan will primarily service Collins for a while until all the other equipment moves over to the Collins backbone.)   

 

This also needs to be communicated to the BUs as another dis-synergy to this LAN synergy.

 

So, I need approval to charge it to either 817 or 91150.  The team is looking for an answer ASAP so that they can get moving on being compliant again.;;;

column1: NET - 009 - Transition into Operational Support
column35:
Transition to Operations, a set of key documentation process hand-offs primarily between Build and Run, requires dedicated time from plan, build, and run network engineering teams to successfully function. Building this into the Project Optimus program timeline will help formalize transitions into operational support, facilitate ongoing network capacity management, and allow for measured improvements to sustaining processes especially when a period of hypercare is determined not to be feasible during transitory project phases. Establishing and maintaining this link allows Operational Support teams sufficient time to enhance relevant support & sustaining processes in alignment with (and to capture business value from) the cadence in which important incremental adjustments/improvements are made during Build.

*For Network Build to Operations*, low-level documentation on the new RTX cages, RTX and Collins device placement, and management IP address assignments for Core WAN Routing & Switching infrastructure can be shared across prior to formal transition and site cutover. This will help facilitate transition to the NOC and NetOps Smart Hands, as well as Monitoring & Network Configuration Management Tools. Suggestion is to leverage the RTX Sharepoint to collect and iterate on site-level architectures, logical architecture diagrams, and core routing & switching configuration management documents.

column35:
Notes from call today:

 
 # New vendor to use Rtime charging for expense recognition purposes, this will need to be decoupled from payment.
 # Payment to be made at 1/12 the contract value at the end of each month
 # At year end, if the actual charging is over or under 5% of the contract, then a true up will occur and be applied to the next invoice.
 # If actual charging is within 5%, then no true up occurs. 

 # In this case, there's an imbalance between expense and cash. 
 # How to handle the two scenarios:

 # Scenario 1:  RTX overpays compared to worked received

 # Is this unallowable
 # Can we increase the rates retroactively?
 # Do we apportion this cost across historically used charge numbers?


 # Scenario 2:  RTX under pays compared to work received.

 # Do we issue a credit and apportion this across historically used charge numbers?
 # Can we decrease the rates retroactively?
